Black lives matter. We are not silent. We reject prejudice and discrimination of any kind.

As we head into summer vacation, we want you to know that even though we aren’t together, we are still with you.

Know that you matter. Know that you are loved, strong, and powerful.

Together, we strive to be an example for all schools within our country to promote equality, equity, and responsible citizenry. We will do our part to make the American public school system excellent, safe, and just for all.

For the sake of all of our scholars, families, and staff, we will not stop learning, caring, teaching, and working hard in any way we can to ensure all Americans benefit from the establishment of Justice and that all Americans can live peacefully in their assurance of the blessings of Liberty.

Are you curious to learn more about Agamim's Hebrew program? Watch this 2nd grade scholar read a story that she wrote and read before our time of Distance Learning!

By studying Hebrew at Agamim, students access one of the three major ancient languages that influenced the development of Western civilization and inspired our intellectual and cultural history. Many of the great thinkers of the past, including the American founding fathers, studied Hebrew, Latin, and Greek. Classical schools today continue to prize the study of one or all of these three ancient languages because of their regular grammatical structure — a feature that helps students learn strong grammar and vocabulary as well as reinforces logical thinking patterns. Like studying mathematics, the inherent logic and order to Hebrew has advantages for nurturing precision and coherence in students’ reasoning and speaking.

To learn more about Agamim please visit our website at www.agamim.org

To donate & support Agamim visit: www.agamim.org/donate-now/

Today is the 50th anniversary of Earth Day. Earth Day started in 1970 and grew into a movement that spurred protections like the Endangered Species Act and the Clean Air Act.
🌎
This Earth Day, we invite you to contemplate what you value and want to protect about our Earth. Are you inspired by the bright stars of the night sky? Have you rowed upon clean, clear streams and lakes? Is it special to know that wild animals share our forests, neighborhoods, and oceans?
🌎
Whatever it is, challenge yourself to learn more about it and explore it from a distance. It may be difficult to feel like there’s much we can do from home this Earth Day, but simply learning is an incredibly important action.
🌎
Agamim gathered virtually for an Earth Day National Parks Exploration this afternoon and were inspired by learning through two exciting websites. We think they are a great place to start your exploration today. Happy (virtual) trails!
🌎

At Agamim, we study and uphold the great American gift of Liberty. Our nation’s founders were classically educated thinkers who understood that to be fully human we needed to be free—free to learn, live, be, and envision a better life for ourselves. This freedom enables us to live our lives in such a manner that brings us safety and happiness, but our application of virtue ensures we know how to be free while governing ourselves with right action.
Here, an Agamim grandmother shares her recent experience of becoming a United States citizen with Agamim second graders. We are proud to learn about immigration and citizenship as part of the Core Knowledge curriculum and that we train our scholars to be knowledgeable citizens of “good moral character”. We also are especially grateful for Agamim family members who volunteer to speak with our scholars!

Congratulations to Agamim 5th grade scholars Kaitlyn (1st Place), Henry (2nd Place), and Elissa (3rd Place) for winning the Hopkins VFW Post #425 Patriot Pen contest! And thank you, Chaplain Kallin, for presenting at their award ceremony! We are grateful for our relationship with our local VFW Post, and the many ways that it helps nurture intentional patriotism and American values within our Agamim family.

Each year more than 132,000 students across the nation enter the VFW’s Patriot’s Pen youth essay contest. This year's theme was: What Makes America Great. The essay contest encourages young minds to examine America’s history, along with their own experiences in modern American society, by drafting a 300- to 400-word essay, expressing their views based on a patriotic theme chosen by the VFW Commander-in-Chief.

post_text: This fall, Agamim 2nd & 3rd grade scholars visited the Historic Cahill School, built in 1864, in one of Edina’s oldest surviving buildings. Now our academy gets to call the City of Edina, MN home! Students learned that the Cahill School served as the center for Edina’s Irish community, acting not only as a school, but also a place to hold meetings, dances, and other social gatherings. They also got to reenact what being a scholar in the building was like and perform a dance routine! All Agamim scholars take meaningful field trips to enrich their academic year, teach leadership skills, and nurture their sense of wonder about the world.

Happy Spring Equinox from these Agamim snow scholars to yours! 🌎

Equinox means "equal night" in Latin. And on the autumnal and spring equinox, that's exactly what happens — there are equal parts day and night. The Earth's orbit puts in just the right place so that it's lined up with the sun, according to NASA. On the equinox, which happens twice a year, both hemispheres receive the same amount of daylight. While the spring equinox occurs in the Northern Hemisphere, the autumnal equinox is occurring in the Southern Hemisphere.

Congratulations to Agamim scholar Caleb T. in grade 6 for being named National Geographic GeoBee Minnesota State Competition Semifinalist by the National Geographic Society!

This is the second level of the National Geographic GeoBee competition, which is now in its 31st year. School GeoBees were held in schools with fourth- through eighth-grade students throughout the state to determine each school champion. School champions then took an online qualifying test, which they submitted to the National Geographic Society.
This year, National Geographic increased the prize money for all State GeoBees. State champions will receive a medal, $1,000 in cash, and other prizes, as well as a trip to Washington, D.C., to represent their state in the National Championship to be held at National Geographic Society headquarters, May 19-22, 2019. Students that come in second and third place will receive cash awards of $300 and $100, respectively.

All are welcome to join us for Caleb’s GeoBee Send Off Assembly on Thursday, March 28th at Agamim!
